Just logging in changed the system cache, created new entries into the logs, and more. Making a copy of the system log is not bad. The way she did it is a problem though. Forensically accepted tools (accepted in the court system) should be used when making copies of data/files/logs/etc.

questions.question: Of the following, which BEST describes the purpose of the Trusted Platform Module (TPM)?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Authenticate each component of the Trusted Computing Base (TCB)
Provide integrity checks for frames received on a network

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Secure storage of decryption keys

A Trusted Platform Module (TPM) is a physical microcontroller used to store and release decryption keys securely. TPMs are frequently utilized for full-disk encryption to ensure data at rest is encrypted. Microsoft’s BitLocker leverages a TPM chip to encrypt data written to the disk.

TPMs are not used to authenticate components of the Trusted Computing Base (TCB). The TCB is a concept that addresses the totality of the components that make up a secure and trusted system. The TPM could be one of those components. Integrity threats within frames are called Cyclic Redundancy Checks (CRC). CRCs are similar to hash functions.

Isolating threads would be a function of the operating system. It is the practice of isolating threads or execution units within a process to prevent them from interfering with each other's data or state. Isolation can be achieved through various mechanisms including locks, semaphores, and memory barriers. This is crucial to maintain the stability and correctness of concurrent software, as it prevents issues like data races and ensures the predictable behavior of threads within a program.

questions.question: An essential asset that handles the most sensitive data or requires one hundred percent uptime would be BEST described as what tier of classification?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Tier zero

Tier zero is reserved for essential assets. These are assets that handle sensitive data and are always required to be available. An example would be a router or file server that an entire organization relies on.

A tier one asset is important, but not equally for every department; for some departments, it may be more important than for others. File shares or local network devices used by a group of employees would be an example of this. Workstations and phones would meet the criteria for a tier two classification. Tier two classifications generally describe non-critical assets that could impact an individual. In this method, there is no tier three.

questions.question: A collection of information, usually sizable and organized for rapid search and retrieval, is known as which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Database

The collection of information or data for search and retrieval purposes is a database. The other choices represent components often associated with databases but do not share the same specific function.

Schema is incorrect because it is a data form where formal definitions of every object are created. Shell is incorrect because it is a user interface. Network is incorrect because it is not a collection of information, instead, it is used to move information.

questions.question: Understanding what makes a password secure is critical. Which of the following passwords is LEAST LIKELY to be compromised?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: jINVGP4nQ66ECSqtDHXPdKfmp62

A combination of length and complexity makes passwords secure. When possible, use passphrases instead of individual words. A passphrase is a combination of words, e.g., YouCan'tHandl3th3Truth@@@. Passphrases are more secure because of increased length and randomness and are easier to remember than shorter but more random passwords. When passphrases are random and long enough, they are very unlikely to exist in a rainbow table.

  • xSfVw4EVdv5r9F! is incorrect because it is less than 16 characters.
  • HotdogGrill1 is incorrect because it's not long enough. This password is vulnerable to dictionary and hybrid attacks.
  • sesquipedalianism is incorrect because it's a valid English word. This password is vulnerable to dictionary attacks.

questions.question: Kat is a developer for an online gaming company. She finds a bug and tries to update the production code but is prevented from doing so. This is MOST LIKELY an example of which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Separation of duties

Separation of duties prohibits a single person from conducting critical tasks by themselves. It adds additional oversight by involving multiple individuals.

Due care is incorrect because it represents acting in a way that a competent person would. Split knowledge is incorrect because it is when the knowledge required to conduct a task is separated between multiple individuals. Defense in depth is incorrect because it refers to the principle that improved security results from layered controls.

questions.question:
Which answer will BEST satisfy the following goals?

  • Reduce unauthorized devices
  • Enforce security policy throughout the network
  • Use identities to perform network management
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Network Access Control (NAC)

Network Access Control (NAC) is the concept of controlling access to a network by authenticating and approving all devices allowed on a network. A common method to do this is through 802.1X. NAC can require that devices maintain a minimum patch or antivirus level before being allowed on the network.

A well-designed NAC program can help achieve the following:

  • Reduce unauthorized devices
  • Enforce security policy throughout the network
  • Use identities to perform network management

A Virtual Private Network (VPN) is an encrypted tunnel. It provides confidentiality between the two endpoints through encryption, which does not satisfy any of the goals of the questions. Network segmentation segregates traffic flows. Firewalls block or allow traffic based on the configuration.

questions.question: A CISO had been informed by a cybersecurity analyst that malware was detected on a workstation. The malware has operated for approximately one week and has been calling out to a command and control (C2) server, sending out proprietary and customer-related information. This malware was found in a new software product that is popular in the cybersecurity industry. The CISO insists the matter should be remediated internally and the vendor should be informed immediately. The cybersecurity analyst agrees but also informs friends employed in other companies on the matter. What principle has the cybersecurity analyst MOST LIKELY violated?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Security Assessment and Testing
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Responsible disclosure

Responsible disclosure is the act of disclosing a vulnerability in a timely manner to the vendor. In this instance, the reporting party must provide a reasonable timeframe for the vendor to address the vulnerability before telling anyone. Failure to do so may result in word spreading before a patch can be distributed, putting the company's reputation and fellow customers at risk. For example, telling people about a vulnerability in a product owned by many people would put those owners at risk of a cyber attack if that knowledge falls into the wrong hands.

A non-compete agreement is a written agreement that an employee will not leave the business and work for the competition or become a competitor for a period of time, e.g. 6 months. A service level agreement is an agreement between a company and a customer in which each party mutually agrees on a service and expectation. Acceptable use policies are policies specifying how a person is allowed to use a particular service.

questions.question: What type of data is HIPAA designed to protect?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Protected health information

Protected health information (PHI) is healthcare data that is collected by healthcare providers and their business associates. It is protected under the Health Insurance Portability and Accessibility Act (HIPAA).

Personally identifiable information (PII) can be used to uniquely identify someone. Examples include names, social security numbers, date of birth, etc.

Proprietary data includes an organization’s intellectual property (IP) and similar information that can help it compete in the marketplace.

questions.question: The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) cipher has a block length of how many bits?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: 128 bits

The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) cipher has a fixed 128-bit long block.

Rijndael, the predecessor of AES, supported 128-, 192-, and 256-bit length blocks. Both support 128-, 192-, and 256-bit length keys.

questions.question: Which of the following should be performed before outsourcing or offshoring sensitive data?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Risk analysis

A risk analysis should be performed before outsourcing or offshoring sensitive data. The analysis is performed to ensure that the offshore or outsourced party is storing the transferred data safely and securely. It must be determined if outsourcing the data creates a greater risk than the organization's risk appetite.

A socioeconomic evaluation could be part of the risk analysis if that is a concern to the business. Performing scans regarding the regulations that the company needs to be in compliance with would also be part of a risk analysis. Awareness training is a completely different topic. It is performed on a regular basis to ensure that users are aware of their information security jobs, tasks, skills, and concerns.

questions.question: When software patches are introduced to fix a security weakness in the system, what function do these patches perform?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Mitigate risk

When patches are introduced to fix a security weakness in the system, they help mitigate risk. Software patching is often performed on a regular basis to maintain the security of production software.

Risk transfer occurs when someone else is involved in the responsibility of managing the risk or the outcome of the event(s) they are worried about. The most common example people use is insurance. There might be a feature that is enhanced when a patch is applied, but the question is about a security patch. Those are not to enhance features, they are to close or fix vulnerabilities in the software. Change management is a process that should be followed in applying the patch, but that is not the function that the question is asking about.

questions.question: What BEST describes a salami attack?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: The unnecessary hashing of plaintext to disrupt data flow
A very disruptive attack that targets as many systems as possible

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Slowly stealing an organization’s assets

A salami attack is a slow attack in which an attacker steals an organization’s assets in very small amounts at a time. This allows the attacker to go undetected and, over time, the stolen assets add up to something significant. For example, someone in accounting transferring corporate money into their personal account, accruing interest for five days, and then giving the corporation back their money, minus the interest.

The rest do not describe particularly named attacks.

questions.question: Mara is planning a security test for a new server that was recently put into production. She is evaluating all the factors that might affect how the system is vulnerable or open to attack. Of the following, what is the LEAST significant factor for Mara to consider?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Security Assessment and Testing

choices.text: Classification and sensitivity of the information stored on the system

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Uptime of the system

The lowest on the list of concerns out of these four options is the uptime of the system. This is because Mara is planning and looking for vulnerabilities at the moment.

Security tests are conducted to verify that a control reduces risk to an acceptable level. These tests include automated scans, tool-assisted penetration tests, and manual attempts to undermine security. They should take place regularly, with attention paid to each of the critical security controls protecting an organization. The availability of testing resources, classification and sensitivity of the information stored on the system, and the system's criticality should all be considered when performing a security test.

questions.question: Of the following, which is a United States law that was the first to implement penalties against those who perpetrate and spread viruses, worms, and other malicious software intended to harm computing systems?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Computer Fraud and Abuse Act

Congress first enacted computer crime law as part of the Comprehensive Crime Control Act (CCCA) of 1984, and it remains enforced today, with several amendments. The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act amendment was enacted in 1986 and was carefully worded to only cover computer crimes that cross state boundaries to avoid infringing on states' rights.

The Sarbanes-Oxley (SOX) Act was created as a response to the actions taken by Enron. They lied about their financial status and cost their customers a huge amount of money. SOX requires companies to ensure that their financial status is accurate and the files are protected. The Computer Security Act of 1987 is a US federal law that was enacted to improve the security and privacy of sensitive information in federal computer systems. The National Infrastructure Protection Plan (NIPP) outlines how government and private sector participants in the critical infrastructure community work together to manage risks and achieve security and resilience outcomes.

questions.question: Which of the following protection solutions is commonly deployed on endpoints to detect advanced persistent threats?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR)

Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) is a protection solution commonly deployed on endpoints to detect Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs). EDR solutions typically incorporate elements of intrusion detection, activity baselines, and machine learning to maximize threat detection capabilities.

A Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) is capable of detecting APTs, but it is deployed on networks rather than endpoints. A bastion host is not a protection solution deployed on endpoints, but a security-hardened host that is commonly placed in an insecure network location to serve as a secure gateway or to securely support key services (e.g. e-mail, FTP). Web security gateways block access to restricted website content and malware, but they do not detect advanced persistent threats.

questions.question: When discussing risk analysis, which of the following is the likelihood of an exploit taken into consideration with the impact of that exploit?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Risk

When discussing risk, it can be defined as the possibility or likelihood that a vulnerability will be exploited, and the resulting impact. The word risk can be used in many different ways when combined with another word such as risk appetite. Risk appetite is the amount of risk an 'entity' is willing to take on in pursuit of its mission.

A threat is defined by the United States (US) National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) as, "Any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, or individuals through an information system via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service."

A vulnerability is a weakness or flaw that can be exploited by the threat actor to bring about the threat or damage. It must be an exploitable weakness. These could be flawed lines of code or an unpatched device, default configurations, default or weak passwords, and so on.

A safeguard is a type of control. There are definitions (NIST for example) that state that a safeguard is the same thing as a control or countermeasure. Other definitions say that those three items are different. If that definition is used control is the generic term, it is inclusive of both countermeasures and safeguards. A control is something that is done to reduce the impact or the likelihood of a threat being realized. A safeguard is preventive in nature and a countermeasure is reactive in nature.

questions.question: Of the following lock types, which is MOST LIKELY vulnerable to bumping?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Tumbler

A tumbler lock is properly opened using its associated key which sets the lock pins into the correct position. However, these locks are vulnerable to bumping. By inserting and agitating a special "bump key", the pins can be forced into the correct position, allowing the cylinder to turn.

Combination, biometric, and keypad locks do not rely on keys and are therefore not vulnerable to bumping.

questions.question: Which of the following is the BEST example of simplex communication?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Car radio

Since a car radio is simple, one-way communication, it is an excellent example of simplex communication. Simplex modes are one-way communication paths established with a transmitter. A car radio can only receive signals, it can't transmit signals, so it's a one-way or simplex device.

A law enforcement radio is incorrect because it can both send and receive communications but must take turns sending and receiving. It is an excellent example of half-duplex communication. A cellular phone is incorrect because it is an example of full-duplex communication. A telephone is two-way communication, just as cellular phones are.

questions.question: What was designed by Netscape to protect communications between a web server and a web browser?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)

Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) is an encryption protocol developed by Netscape to protect the communications between a web server and a web browser. SSL uses asymmetric encryption and Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to securely exchange a client-generated session key, after which all traffic is encrypted using symmetric encryption. SSL has been superseded by Transport Layer Security (TLS).

Challenge Handshake Application Protocol (CHAP) is an option within the Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) for authentication. It was an improvement from the previous Password Authentication Protocol (PAP) which sent the password in clear text. CHAP hashes the password in combination with a challenge number called a Number used ONCE (NONCE). Internet Key Exchange (IKE) is a symmetric key exchange protocol found within Internet Protocol Security (IPSec).

questions.question: What BEST defines a Smurf attack?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security

choices.text: Spoofing the source IP address with the victim's address and flooding the broadcast address with ICMP echo requests
Sending fragmented IP packets with oversized payloads to the victim’s machine
Spoofing the source IP address with the victim's address, causing the victim to reply to itself

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Spoofing the source IP address with the victim's address and flooding the broadcast address with ICMP echo requests

A Smurf attack spoofs the source IP address with the victim's address and floods the broadcast address with ICMP requests. This causes devices on the network to send an ICMP reply to the victim for each ICMP request sent by the attacker. This overwhelms the victim and can cause the system to crash. A Smurf attack is a Denial of Service (DoS) attack.

If there is a higher likelihood of a hash collision, the hash algorithm is susceptible to the birthday attack. Spoofing the source address as the address of the victim is called a LAND attack and is also a DoS attack. Sending improperly fragmented IP packets with oversized payloads is called a teardrop attack. This too is a DoS attack.

questions.question: A corporation has recently begun using some software services from another company. They are concerned that their users may be using other services without approval. What tool can they use to confirm if this is true or not?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB)

A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) is a security tool or service that helps organizations secure their use of cloud services. It acts as an intermediary between cloud service providers and users, providing visibility, control, and security features to protect data and applications in the cloud. CASBs offer features such as data encryption, access control, threat detection, and compliance monitoring to address security concerns associated with cloud computing. So, it is able to detect what services the users are utilizing.

Data Loss Prevention (DLP) is a set of technologies and strategies designed to protect sensitive data from unauthorized access, sharing, or theft. DLP solutions monitor and control data in motion, at rest, and in use to prevent data breaches, leaks, or loss. They use a combination of policies, encryption, monitoring, and blocking mechanisms to enforce data security policies and prevent confidential information from being exposed to unauthorized parties. DLP solutions are commonly used in organizations to safeguard sensitive data, comply with regulatory requirements, and mitigate the risks of data breaches.

An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is a security tool or software application that monitors network or system activities for malicious activities or policy violations. IDS can detect unauthorized access attempts, malware activity, network scanning, and other suspicious behavior. It works by analyzing network traffic, system logs, and event data to identify potential security threats.

A Web Application Firewall (WAF) is a security tool designed to protect web applications from various cyber threats and attacks. It operates at the application layer of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model, monitoring and filtering HTTP traffic between a web application and the internet. A WAF can detect and block malicious traffic, such as SQL injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF), and other web-based attacks.

questions.question: If antimalware software looks at the characteristics of code and how it may interact with the system looking for suspicious behavior, what type of detection is MOST LIKELY being used?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Heuristic

Heuristic detection, sometimes called behavior detection, analyzes the characteristics and structure of code to detect malware. If the code has too many negative characteristics, it will be quarantined.

Signature detection compares hashes of known malware to software on a system. Sandbox is not a detection method. Sandboxing is a technique that lets the malware run in an isolated environment so that it can be analyzed. Reputation detection is similar to signature detection. Firewalls often have dynamic blacklists that block IP addresses known to be malicious, commonly called reputation detection.

questions.question: ACME Corporation has just recovered the critical computer systems from a major fire in their data center. However, it will change the way the business operates for years to come. Which plan will likely be MOST useful at this point?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Business Continuity Plan

A Business Continuity Plan (BCP) deals with both preparing for a disaster and aiding after a disaster has occurred. The primary goal of a BCP is to reduce disaster-related risks to an acceptable level. A BCP is broader than a Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) and is focused on the business as a whole, not just IT equipment.

A Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) is incorrect because it is a short-term plan designed to get systems back online as fast as possible. NIST defines the DRP as a written plan for processing critical applications in the event of a major hardware or software failure or destruction of facilities.

The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) is the first plan used because of the fire. Evacuating everyone out of the building safely is the first priority and that is handled through the ERP.

If a contingency plan is developed by the business it would be used before the DRP. NIST defines the contingency plan as the first plan used by the enterprise risk managers to determine what happened, why, and what to do. It may point to the Continuity Of Operations Plan (COOP) or Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP) for major disruptions.

questions.question: What BEST describes the cause of a buffer overflow?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security

choices.text: When too much data is accepted as input
When input data is not sanitized and contains malicious commands
When the application does not release memory after it no longer needs it

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: When too much data is accepted as input

Buffer overflows occur when an application does not validate input data length. They occur when too much data is provided and the allocated memory space overflows. This generally causes the program to crash and, in some circumstances, the attacker can replace legitimate code execution with their own set of instructions.

If the input is not sanitized and contains a malicious command, it could be an SQL injection or command injection attack. Inadequate memory does not cause a buffer overflow, it can cause an application to fail, but not a buffer overflow. If the application does not release memory, it is a memory management issue.

questions.question: Ashley is a penetration tester who successfully captured a system’s password file. The compromised system only requires a minimum of eight characters for each password. She uses a rainbow table with trillions of passwords to hash values to find any matches; however, none are found. Of the following, what is MOST LIKELY the reason none of the hash values match the rainbow table?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)

choices.text: A salt was used with the hash
None of the passwords are in the rainbow table

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: A salt was used with the hash

Adding a salt to a password hash enhances security. A salt is a unique random value combined with the password before hashing. This prevents identical passwords from having the same hash, thwarting precomputed attacks and increasing complexity, making it harder for attackers to crack passwords.

A password not being in the rainbow table is not likely. The hackers have a rainbow table with precomputed hashes for passwords at least 16 characters long and all smaller than that. The potential that the rainbow computed incorrectly is slightly possible, but if she is using any of the normal products that pen testers use, this would not be a problem. The system being a honeypot is irrelevant to the scenario. Ashley has a password file, she is trying to figure out the passwords based on that file. The file only contains the hash values for the passwords or the passwords with salts, which is more likely here.

questions.question: Jim is a facility manager for a national hotel chain. His organization outsources Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) maintenance to different vendors across the country. Some of the vendors request to have monitoring equipment installed at the location they support. What is the MOST critical step that must be done before allowing the vendors to install monitoring equipment?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management

choices.text: Establish a supply chain risk management program
Segment the network using Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs)
Establish policies and procedures that each vendor must follow
Require each vendor sign a non-disclosure agreement

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Establish a supply chain risk management program

Establishing a supply chain risk management program is an essential step before allowing third parties access to internal systems. Each vendor must be assessed to ensure they do not introduce more risk than the organization's risk appetite allows. Organizations often use Security Organization Control 1 (SOC-1), SOC-2, and SOC-3 audit reports to show compliance with internal security controls that can be used when assessing vendor risk.

The risk management program would include the other three answers, where appropriate. It would include control over the network using Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs). Policies and procedures would be created, and the vendor would be notified of their compliance requirements. A Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) would also be included and should be one of the first steps in managing the risks the vendors bring with them.

questions.question: Chloe and Andy are planning an attack on Chloe’s organization. Chloe is a disgruntled employee who sits next to the IT department and has insider knowledge of the environment. Every time she learns the IT department is away on a work outing, she eats her sandwich at a specific table next to a window that Andy can see. Andy wants to conduct the attack when the IT department is away to reduce the likelihood of being caught. Of the following, this information exchange is BEST described as what?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Covert channel

A covert channel is the disclosure of information in an unauthorized manner. Covert channels can be very sophisticated and difficult to detect. In this scenario, Chloe and Andy are conducting a timed covert channel.

There are two types of covert channels:

  • Storage: exchange of information by writing data to a common storage medium that another process can read.
  • Timing: exchange of information through the use of timing. An example of this could be that a shared resource is used or not used.

A storage channel is a type of covert channel, however, she is using a timing channel. Sitting at the window at lunchtime is the timing of the event of her eating her sandwich.

Information flow is a model used to discover where information is actually flowing within a business. Overt channel is fabricated.

questions.question: Of the following antivirus detection methods, which scans for fingerprints of known malware?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Signature-based detection

The primary technique used by antivirus software is signature-based detection. It relies on having a fingerprint (hash) of malware that the software regularly scans for and quarantines when a match is found. Signature-based detection requires fewer system resources, but the main drawback is that if there is no reported signature for specific malware, that malware can run undetected unless stopped by other methods.

Reputation-based analysis can be performed on email addresses and web addresses as it is based on the history of the address. Heuristic means to discover or learn. So, a heuristic scanner has the ability to look for suspicious behavior that could indicate a new virus or threat. Command and Control (CnC) is used by bots and zombies to communicate with the control center that sends it commands to attack in some way.

questions.question: What BEST describes the purpose of the Diffie-Hellman algorithm?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Key distribution

The Diffie-Hellman algorithm is used to securely distribute symmetric keys through a clear text connection.

Diffie-Hellman (DH) is an asymmetric algorithm that is not used for encryption. It is only used for the exchange of a symmetric key between two parties so that symmetric encryption can be performed. The DH algorithm does not have public or private keys as it is essentially a math proof. The work done by the sender and receiver proves the math of the other. The end of the calculations performed by both sides will be the exact same and that number is the symmetric key. Meaning, DH cannot be used for digital signatures.

questions.question: Of the following, which BEST describes a type 2 authentication factor?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Smart card

Smart cards are "something you have" or a type 2 authentication factor. They are rarely used by themselves but are commonly combined with other authentication factors, providing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA).

Personal Identification Number (PIN) and security questions are both "something you know" or a type 1 authentication factor. A palm vein scan is "something you are" or a type 3 authentication factor.

questions.question: The STRIDE threat model is used for assessing threats against applications or operating systems. Which of the following is part of STRIDE?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Spoofing

Microsoft developed STRIDE, a way of categorizing threats. STRIDE stands for Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information disclosure, Denial of Service (DoS), and Elevation of privilege. A spoofing attack tries to imitate a trusted user, thereby fooling the system into accepting the imposter as the original entity. An example is an Internet Protocol (IP) spoofing attack. In IP spoofing, hackers replace a valid IP address with a phony one to impersonate a genuine system or keep their identity a secret.

The other options are not part of the STRIDE threat model. Spamming is a continual form of security risk that uses repetition by way of email. Replay attacks involve capturing a legitimate authentication attempt and replaying it for malicious purposes. Discover is not relevant.

questions.question: What does the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) 3.1 score of 3.8 indicate?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Security Assessment and Testing
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Low vulnerability

The CVSS 3.1 scoring system rates vulnerabilities on a low, medium, high, or critical scale. They are defined by the following range:

  • 0.1-3.9 (Low)
  • 4.0-6.9 (Medium)
  • 7-8.9 (High)
  • 9-10 (Critical)

questions.question: Of the following options, which BEST estimates the potential loss an asset may suffer from a specific threat?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Annualized Loss Expectancy (ALE)

Annualized Loss Expectancy (ALE) measures exactly the one-year financial loss an asset may suffer from a specifically identified threat.

The formula is ALE = SLE (single loss expectancy) x ARO (annualized rate of occurrence), and it is used to determine risk and insurance requirements based on the potential for failure.

Threat modeling is incorrect because it is the process of identifying, understanding, and categorizing potential threats; it does not assign an asset’s value. Asset value calculation is incorrect because it does not estimate the loss an asset may suffer from a specific threat. Threat evaluation is a fictitious term.

questions.question: When disaster strikes, what should be the highest priority for every organization?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Knowledge of employee whereabouts

Each of these choices may be considered a high priority, but it is internationally understood that employee safety is paramount. Employee safety should always be the top priority when designing a Business Continuity Plan (BCP) or Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP).

These plans do focus on recovering functionality, especially for the company's highest-valued assets (if they are servers and such). To recover smoothly, it will take an established chain of command structure.

questions.question: Which of the following is the term for customizing an existing set of security controls for an information system?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Tailoring

Tailoring is customizing a set of existing security controls to align with an organization’s mission and objectives. Examples of blueprints that can be tailored are ISO 27001 & 27002 and the NIST Cybersecurity Framework.

Scoping is reviewing and selecting initial security controls for a new information system. Alteration and white boxing are not normal terms used within information security. There are white box tests, however, they should be referred to as open box tests or something similar to remove the color.

questions.question: An organization is implementing an authentication system for a high-risk system where unauthorized access could have serious effects. Which of the following error rates should they be looking to MINIMIZE?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: FAR

Biometric authentication systems can produce various types of errors, including:

  • False positives: False acceptances or Type 2 errors are when a system incorrectly authenticates an unauthorized user. The false acceptance rate (FAR) is calculated as the ratio of false acceptances to valid authentications.
  • False negatives: False rejections or Type 1 errors are when a system fails to authenticate a legitimate user. The ratio of false rejections to valid authentications is the false rejection rate (FRR).

The crossover error rate (CER) or equal error rate (EER) is when the FRR equals the FAR.

questions.question: The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is trying to convince the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) that a new policy should be created to address an ongoing issue with asset labeling and the lack of uniformity currently in the workplace. Which statement would BEST address the concerns of the CISO?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security

choices.text: Labeling assets would allow all employees to know the importance of the information or items and handle them appropriately.
By labeling assets, the company would eliminate liability associated with them during a breach.
Labeling assets would help determine Single Loss Expectancy (SLE) after a hurricane.
Labeling allows information to be declassified at a faster rate, freeing storage space.

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Labeling assets would allow all employees to know the importance of the information or items and handle them appropriately.

Labeling all assets would allow for their classification and an organized manner in which to determine the values of items and data within a company.

Labeling assets may oftentimes not eliminate liability associated with a company if a breach were to occur. The breach could be due to a variety of reasons, but not necessarily directly from a lack of asset labeling. A natural disaster that is not likely to occur frequently would not be the strongest justification for moving forward with asset labeling. Labeling may allow for declassifying information at a faster rate, but this isn't as great of a concern as potentially mishandling sensitive data. In many cases, companies may opt to destroy or erase data in some way versus declassifying it.

questions.question: Data Encryption Standard (DES) uses how many encryption rounds?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: 16

Data Encryption Standard (DES) was published in 1977 as a standard cryptosystem for government communications. DES has a key size of 64 bits; however, 8 bits are used for parity, giving DES an effective key length of 56 bits. DES has a block size of 64 bits, and each block is put through 16 rounds of encryption functions.

questions.question: Willow is working with the Information Technology (IT) department to determine where they can and should have Intrusion Detection Systems (IDSs) installed. They are looking at both host and network-based systems while discussing the pros and cons of each. Which of the following is a common problem with network-based IDSs?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations

choices.text: Network-based IDSs cannot consistently determine if an attack was successful or not.
Network-based IDSs have limited encapsulation detection and analyzing abilities.
Network-based IDSs can only manage individual network packets received by the host.

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Network-based IDSs cannot consistently determine if an attack was successful or not.

Since Network-Based IDSs (NIDSs) cannot see process information on each host, they cannot consistently determine if an attack was successful.

NIDSs usually have the ability to detect and analyze encapsulation. Network-based IDSs can manage more than individual network packets. The cost of the NIDS may be a factor in system acquisition but should not be considered a problem for network-based IDSs.

questions.question: Fire detection systems are used throughout structures to protect employees in the building. Which fire detection system reacts to a change in ambient temperature?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Heat

Heat detection systems react to the significant changes in temperature that are caused by a fire. They can prevent fires before they occur by detecting rising heat levels. Heat and humidity detectors are used together to prevent environmental damage in a data center.

Ionization is incorrect because it uses an ionization chamber and a source of ionizing radiation to detect smoke. Photoelectric is incorrect because it uses a small light source inside the alarm that is captured by a light sensor and detects smoke. Electric is incorrect because it is a generic title given to standard fire alarms, which are connected via wires rather than battery-operated.

questions.question: Without using a hypervisor, a word processor wanting to save a file would need to access which Computer Processing Unit (CPU) ring?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Ring 3

User applications, including word processors, reside in Ring 3, the least secure and trusted of the rings.

  • Applications (3)
  • Hardware Drivers (2)
  • Operating System (1)
  • Kernel (0)

As protection layer numbers decrease, a higher level of security is required.

questions.question: While responding to a security incident, an analyst wants to determine if malware has spread from the originating workstation to any others within the organization. Upon observing this incident, the workstation was immediately physically isolated from all networks. The analyst recommends working alongside a co-worker to analyze the code within the malware and determine its intent. Management's top priority is ensuring the continued function of the business while managing the impact this attack may have overall. What would MOST LIKELY be appropriate in this situation?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Security Assessment and Testing

choices.text: Review logs to determine if and where the malware spread
Ask employees to report odd behavior at their workstations

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Review logs to determine if and where the malware spread

The first thing to do after removing the infected PC from a network is to determine if the malware has spread. This can be done by reviewing the Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) and seeing which IP addresses the infected machine interacted with. This would be the fastest way to determine if other workstations need to be taken offline too.

Individually asking employees questions will simply slow down the investigation. Shutting down all workstations immediately would have potentially drastic effects on the workplace as a whole and may be completely unnecessary. Immediately notifying customers of a breach would result in unnecessary attention when a breach hasn't been confirmed yet. If one machine was infected with malware and all customer info was encrypted, it likely doesn't have to be reported. It's important that a business try not to damage its reputation with customers. Unnecessarily damaging the company's reputation could impose serious financial hardships, especially after practicing due care by encrypting the information anyway.

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST LIKELY valid classification label used in military or government environments?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Asset Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Secret

The classification secret is used in military and government environments.

In military and government environments, the classifications are:

  • Unclassified
  • Sensitive but Unclassified
  • Confidential
  • Secret
  • Top Secret

In private organizations, the standard classifications are:

  • Public
  • Sensitive
  • Private
  • Confidential
  • For official use only

questions.question: Daisy has been working with the Business Continuity (BC) teams to identify potential threats that have not been addressed appropriately or at all by the corporation. They have just identified a threat that has a low likelihood of occurrence and a low impact score. What would be the best response to this threat?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Risk acceptance

When a threat is not likely to be realized and will have little impact, an organization should document and accept the risk. Risk acceptance does not mean choosing to ignore the risk but rather concluding that doing something about the risk is more costly than the risk itself.

Risk transfer involves the sharing of the burden of the threat with another. The most common example given is insurance policies, but it can also include contracts and End User Licensing Agreements (EULA) to name a couple more. Risk reduction or risk mitigation includes tools or actions taken to reduce the change or impact. This could be a tool like an Intrusion Prevention System (IPS), encryption, policies, and so on. Risk avoidance would not be used in a risky activity to begin with, or to stop one when identified.

questions.question: Which of the following software development models is BEST characterized by rigid linear progression?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Waterfall model

When software development follows a staggered approach of rigid, well-defined stages, this is considered the waterfall model. A waterfall model of system development contains all the steps required to take a project from conception to completion. Generally, you cannot skip or go back to steps using the waterfall model.

The Agile software development model is an iterative and flexible approach, emphasizing collaboration, adaptability, and customer feedback throughout the development process for efficient and responsive project delivery. Scrum is an Agile framework for project management and product development. It emphasizes collaboration, adaptability, and iterative progress through short, time-boxed work periods called sprints that maintain regular reviews and adjustments. Software Capability Maturity Model (SCMM) is a framework that assesses and improves the process maturity of software development organizations. It defines five maturity levels, guiding companies from initial chaos to continuous optimization, and enhancing software development and management practices.

questions.question: Which type of document is used to reinforce trust between an organization and the security assessment supplier?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Nondisclosure agreement

Security assessments often require several legal documents in the delivery of a final product. A nondisclosure agreement reinforces trust between the organization and the security assessment supplier by ensuring that the confidential materials and ideas used by both parties are not disclosed to others without consent.

A statement of work is incorrect because this simply outlines the tasks and deliverables the assessment supplier will provide. Work commencement is incorrect because it is an authorization to commence work. A noncompete agreement is incorrect because it does not restrict the security assessor from disclosure.

questions.question: Onyx works within the Information Technology (IT) department and has been deploying new routers and firewalls over the last year. He has been following the process that they have documented as the configuration and deployment of these devices has occurred. Which of the following processes ensures all additions to the IT data center are tracked, documented, controlled, and audited?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Change management

Change management requires documentation and signatures from authorized personnel to avoid rogue changes that could affect an organization's infrastructure. Any changes made to critical systems that could impact organizational performance require change management controls. The process greatly reduces the risk associated with updates and upgrades.

Configuration management is typically used to manage the configurable system settings. That is part of what Onyx is doing, but not all of it. Risk management is the assessment of threats and vulnerabilities to minimize the likelihood and the resulting impact of any incidents or attacks. Asset management would be part of what is happening here, as the routers and firewalls are corporate assets. However, asset management manages the lifecycle of the asset. The question is only about the deployment.

questions.question: The DevOps approach focuses on three components to help decrease the time required to develop, test, and deploy software changes. Of the following, which is NOT a standard component of the DevOps model?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Information Technology security

Information Technology (IT) security is not a standard component of the DevOps model.

The DevOps model has three overlapping components: software development, quality assurance, and operations. The DevOps model is closely aligned with the Agile development approach and aims to dramatically decrease the time required to develop, test, and deploy software changes. What is not part of that is the security of the Information Technology (IT) environment.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST refers to the level of privileges granted to a user?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Entitlement

Entitlement refers to the level of privileges granted to a user. If a user has been granted access to an object, they are entitled to it.

The other three options are not used to describe the level of privileges that are granted. Scope of role comes close if the access control system is a Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) system, but it is not usually stated that way. Aggregation is the idea of adding various things together and can be used in many different situations. It is a problem when dealing with databases. The concern is that a user may be able to aggregate different pieces of information together that disclose a piece of information that has a higher level of classification than they should be able to see. Seniority is a status in business, but not in access control.

questions.question: Of the following, a hash MOST LIKELY provides what?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Integrity & Authentication

A hashing algorithm is a one-way mathematical operation that can accept an input value of any length and generate a fixed-length output. The output cannot be mathematically reversed. Hashing algorithms are used to validate a file's or message’s integrity. They are also used to store passwords. A password is hashed, and the authentication server stores the output. The only way to reproduce the hash is to know the original value. Using hashing algorithms in this way provides for authentication.

Hashing does not provide confidentiality in any way. The original data is not protected, if that is the desire, symmetric algorithms such as the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) would be used. Identification is asserting a claim, such as a username, user ID, email address, etc. Authorization is the process of granting an appropriate level of permissions such as read, write, etc. Neither identification nor authorization involves hashes.

questions.question: Which of the following is characterized legally by securing protections on data critical to an organization's operations?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Trade secrets

Trade secrets legally secure protections on data critical to an organization's operations. This intellectual property usually requires other legal support, such as Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDA) and non-compete clauses. An example of a trade secret is the Coca-Cola formula.

Trademarks represent the goodwill that the customers have for a company and their products. For example the shape of the Coca-Cola bottle, the flying windows logo for Microsoft Windows, and any car emblem, among so many others. Trademarks can be registered, but it is not a requirement. If there is a conflict later on, it will be necessary to prove when that logo was first used.

Copyrights protect content for movies, music, books, and software among other things. Copyright covers the expression of an idea. For example, the exact layout of this question and the unique explanation. This too can be registered, but does not have to be registered. The same would be true for the copyright if not registered, it will be necessary to prove when the content was created.

Patents must be registered. Patents can be applied to ideas that are novel, useful, and non-obvious. The idea is registered and is the property of the person/company that the patent has been granted to. The holder of the patent has control over the idea and its use for a period of approximately 20 years. The RSA algorithm is an example of something that was granted a patent. It was the first algorithm that had two distinct keys, the public and private key pair.

questions.question: Mr. Kennard is setting up the Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) for the corporation he works for. They have a policy that requires emails to be signed at all times. He is assessing the cryptographic algorithms that he can use for this. Which of the following is an asymmetric algorithm that uses public and private keys?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Rivest, Shamir, & Adleman (RSA)

Rivest, Shamir, & Adleman (RSA) is an asymmetric algorithm that uses public and private keys. RSA is often used to distribute symmetric encryption keys because asymmetric encryption is computationally expensive and can’t be used to efficiently encrypt large amounts of data. When using asymmetric algorithms like RSA, if a message is encrypted using the private key, it can only be decrypted using the public key; this rule also applies in reverse. If a message is encrypted with the public key, it can only be decrypted using the private key.

Diffie-Hellman (DH) is an asymmetric algorithm. Mr. Diffie and Mr. Hellman wrote a paper in 1976 that theorized public and private keys. However, the algorithm they came up with does not work that way. It is an algorithm for the purpose of exchanging a symmetric key only. They were unsuccessful in finding the math to use public and private keys. RSA did that in 1977. AES and Blowfish are both symmetric algorithms that are used to protect the confidentiality of data, voice, or video.

questions.question: Which of the following is an interpreted programming language?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: JavaScript

JavaScript is an interpreted programming language. It is interpreted on the fly. You can think of an interpreter next to a speaker that translates what they are saying into another language for the audience.

C, c++,  Erlang, Haskell, Rust, Go, and Fortran are all compiled programming languages. Compiled languages use a compiler to generate an executable file.

questions.question: Each employee in an organization has a collection of labels assigned to them, and access rules are defined as combinations of these labels. Which of the following does this BEST describe?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: ABAC

Access control can be managed under several different models, including:

  • Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC): ABAC defines and assigns various attributes to users, and access to resources is governed based on combinations of attributes. For example, an IT manager may have attributes granting them access to IT resources and management-level resources.
  • Mandatory Access Control (MAC): MAC assigns classification labels to subjects and objects to govern access. An example of MAC is the system used by some governments, which includes classifications such as Unclassified, Confidential, Secret, and Top Secret, with compartments within each level.
  • Discretionary Access Control (DAC): DAC allows the owner of an asset to manage access to that asset via an ACL. This is the default access control model used by most operating systems.
  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): RBAC defines groups based on various roles and assigns privileges to these groups. Users are assigned to a group and inherit the privileges associated with it. Group Policies in Windows use RBAC. RBAC is good for protecting against privilege creep, because removing a user from a group removes all the associated permissions.
  • Rule-Based Access Control: Rule-based access controls define rules that govern access to a system. Firewalls are an example of a system that uses rule-based access control to manage traffic flowing through it.
  • Risk-Based Access Control: Risk-based access control assesses the risk posed by a request before granting or denying it. For example, some resources may only be accessible from on-prem networks or trusted devices.

questions.question: A senior security officer is training several new employees on the Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) triad and how to apply it at their organization. They are discussing which principle corresponds to authorized subjects having timely and uninterrupted access to objects. Which principle is being reviewed?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Availability

The third principle of the Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) triad is availability. The focus of availability is to ensure reliability and access to system resources or data. An example of an attack that disrupts availability is a Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack. Planning for power outages and using Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPS) helps ensure the availability of a given system.

Authorization is the granting of permissions to verified users such as read, write, execute, etc. Confidentiality is about keeping secrets secret. It is necessary to protect company data, phone conversations, and so on. Accountability is usually used in Identity and Access Management (IAM) as the act of logging user activity so that they can be held accountable for their actions.

questions.question: The Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria (TCSEC) and Information Technology Security Evaluation Criteria (ITSEC) were replaced by which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: The International Standard for System Security Evaluation Criteria (ISSSEC)

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Common Criteria

The U.S. Department of Defense-developed Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria (TCSEC), and the European Union-developed Information Technology Security Evaluation Criteria (ITSEC) were both replaced with Common Criteria. Common Criteria is published as International Standards Organization (ISO) Standard 15408. It was developed as a standard for evaluating information technology products. Arguably, ISO 15408 is the international standard for system security evaluation criteria, but that is not the real name. Common Criteria has seven levels:

  • EAL1 – Functionally tested
  • EAL2 – Structurally tested
  • EAL3 – Methodically tested and checked
  • EAL4 – Methodically designed, tested, and reviewed
  • EAL5 – Semiformally designed and tested
  • EAL6 – Semiformally verified designed and tested
  • EAL7 – Formally verified design and tested

All three of those documents, TCSEC, ITSEC, and Common Criteria, are evaluation criteria. International Standards Organization (ISO) 27000 is the introductory document to the 27000 series of documents. ISO 27001 and 2 are used to develop Information Security Governance Systems (ISMS). The International Standard for System Security Evaluation Criteria (ISSSEC) is not a real standard.

questions.question: Which motion detector senses changes in the electromagnetic field surrounding a monitored object?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Security Operations
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: A capacitance motion detector

A capacitance motion detector contains an electromagnetic field surrounding the device. When an object is present, changes to that field are detected and trigger an alarm.

An infrared motion detector is incorrect because it monitors for significant or meaningful changes in an area's infrared lighting pattern. A wave pattern motion detector is incorrect because it transmits a consistent low ultrasonic frequency signal into a monitored area to discover significant or meaningful changes or disturbances in the reflected pattern. A passive audio motion detector is incorrect because it detects abnormal sounds in the monitored area.

questions.question: Acme Inc. uses an access control system that relies on the use of classification labels. These classification labels are used to understand the object and then assign a clearance level. When a user tries to access a file, these two pieces of information are used to determine if they should be granted access or not. What access control model is being employed by Acme Inc.?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Mandatory Access Control (MAC)

Mandatory Access Control (MAC) is a security model and access control mechanism used in computer systems to enforce strict and centralized control over the access and manipulation of resources. MAC ensures that access rights are determined and set by system administrators or security policies, rather than by individual users or processes. This makes it particularly useful in high-security environments, such as government agencies, military organizations, and critical infrastructure systems. MAC is a stringent access control model that provides a high level of security by enforcing predetermined and centralized access policies based on security labels, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or data leakage in sensitive environments.

Discretionary Access Control (DAC) is a type of access control mechanism used in computer systems to manage and regulate access to resources based on the discretion of resource owners or administrators. In a DAC system, resource owners have the authority to determine who can access their resources and what level of access those users are granted.

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) is an access control mechanism used in computer systems and databases to manage and enforce access rights based on users' roles and responsibilities within an organization. In RBAC, access permissions are assigned to roles rather than individual users, making it easier to manage and enforce access control in large and complex environments.

Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) is an advanced access control mechanism that uses a set of attributes and policies to make access control decisions. In ABAC, access permissions are determined based on the attributes associated with users, resources, and environmental conditions. This approach provides more fine-grained and dynamic control over access compared to traditional access control models like RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) and DAC (Discretionary Access Control).

questions.question: Zac works with the Chief Information Security Officer's (CISO) office. They have been inquiring about the best path to take to improve their software development capabilities. Which of the following describes a software development approach that incorporates automated cybersecurity checks into its CI/CD pipeline automation?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security

choices.text: Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiate, Information disclosure, Denial of service, Escalation (STRIDE)
Process for Attack Simulation and Threat Analysis (PASTA)

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Development Security Operations (DevSecOps)

DevSecOps is a software development approach incorporating automated cybersecurity checks into its CI/CD pipeline automation. DevSecOps is a combination of Development (Dev), Security (Sec), and Operations (Ops).

DevOps describes a software development approach that utilizes a CI/CD pipeline for automation without having automated cybersecurity checks incorporated into that pipeline. DevOps is a portmanteau of Development (Dev) and Operations (Ops). STRIDE and PASTA are not software development approaches but refer to threat modeling methodologies. They are used to find flaws in application environments through systematic analysis.

questions.question: The new information security manager, Ugo, has been exploring how risk is being handled within the company. He has recently been discussing the concept of risk with the Chief Executive Officer (CEO). Since Ugo prefers the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication (SP) 800-137, he knows that risk is defined using which two critical concepts?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Likelihood and Impact

NIST defines risk in many different documents that are all very similar. NIST SP 80-137 defines risk as, "A measure of the extent to which an entity is threatened by a potential circumstance or event, and typically a function of: (i) the adverse IMPACTS that would arise if the circumstance or event occurs; and (ii) the LIKELIHOOD of occurrence."

A vulnerability is a weakness or flaw that allows the threat to be realized. The threat is the harm or damage that could be experienced and impact the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of an asset. A safeguard is a control that is added to protect the asset. NIST considers the terms safeguard, control, and countermeasure as equal. Some people consider safeguarding as a preventive control. For example, putting a laptop in a safe will safeguard it, making it very difficult for someone to steal.

questions.question: Of the following, which algorithm is considered to be a stream cipher?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Rivest Cipher (RC) 4

Rivest Cipher (RC) 4 is a stream cipher and has a variable key size of 40-2048 bits. It was developed in 1987 and was commonly used in Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)/Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP), as well as Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA); however, it is no longer considered secure.

Blowfish, Rivest Cipher (RC) 5, and Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) are all block ciphers.

questions.question: Of the following, which is MOST LIKELY to be considered spyware?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Key logger

A key logger is software that records each keystroke a user makes. Key loggers can be used to steal credentials, uncover private information, or reveal additional vulnerabilities in an information system. Spyware is a type of malware that gathers sensitive information about a victim.

Ransomware is malware that is used to encrypt a company's data and then hold the key that will decrypt the data for a ransom. The ransom could be in the millions of dollars. Phishing is when an email is sent to many people with the intention of getting someone to click on a nefarious link. The link can do a variety of things, including taking a user to a fake website or starting a download to the user's computer that leads to damage. Shoulder surfing is when a person literally looks over someone else's shoulder to watch them enter a password or Personally Identifiable Number (PIN). The point is to steal that 'secret' piece of information, allowing the shoulder surfer to access the user's account.

questions.question: When a password does not change frequently and is used for each login session, what is it MOST LIKELY considered?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Static

A static password is one that does not change frequently. Static tokens and passwords aren't as secure as dynamic ones.

Fixed is not a term used for such passwords. Dynamic passwords change each time a session expires. Examples of dynamic passwords are token-generated passwords and one-time-use passwords. The User ID (UID) needs to be unique, not the password. It is good practice to have different passwords for each account, but unique is used to describe the UID, not the password.

questions.question: Which type of control requires identifying occurrences to perform its functions?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Detective

Detective controls are deployed to detect or identify unwanted or unauthorized activity. These controls are frequently deployed after an event to ensure that future occurrences are discovered. Detective controls do not directly block or prevent unwanted activity. Detective controls include security cameras, motion detectors, and virus scans.

Corrective and recovery controls are very similar to each other. A corrective control takes something from a non-functional state to a functional one. A Disaster Recovery (DR) site is a good example. If there has been a fire in the data center, the DR site allows the business to get back to a functioning state. It is not normal though, as they do not have all systems running and they are in different locations. If the data center is rebuilt after the fire and all systems are returned to a ‘normal’ state, then a recovery control has been used. Recovery controls take broken or only functional environments/systems back to a normal condition.

A deterrent control is something that, when it is known by the would-be attacker, they decide not to do their bad deed as they are deterred from that behavior. An armed guard deters someone from breaking into a building. Or a policy that when violated could cost someone their job is also a deterrent.

questions.question: What BEST describes Kerckhoff's Principle?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: Only the keys need to be kept secret
That both the algorithm and keys be kept secret
That only the algorithm needs to be kept secret
That no single person be given the entire decryption key

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Only the keys need to be kept secret

Auguste Kerckhoff wrote a paper in the late 1800s detailing six key principles regarding cryptography. There is one principle that is still commonly discussed today and often referred to as Kerckoff’s principle. This principle assumes that everything about a cryptographic system is public knowledge except for the key. This has the benefit of validating an algorithm by the broader security community instead of relying on the insiders who created the algorithm. This assumption can also discourage people from neglecting to secure the keys through a false sense of security.

So, the key must be kept secret, but the algorithm should be public and well-examined. Keeping the algorithms secret is a mistake because it needs to be analyzed by many people to ensure that there are no holes in the math. It is common for people to have the entire decryption key, in fact, that is what is normal.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT one of the primary goals of integrity?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering

choices.text: To prevent unauthorized users from making system modifications
To prevent authorized users from making improper modifications

questions.explanation:
Correct answer: To prevent unauthorized data access

Preventing unauthorized data access is not an integrity goal but a confidentiality goal.

Integrity goals include the consistency of data and the prevention of unauthorized modifications by unauthorized and authorized users. Clark and Wilson defined these three ‘incorrect’ answers as the three goals of integrity in their security model that was published in 1987.

Rule 1: Prevent unauthorized users from making any modifications.

Rule 2: Prevent authorized users from making improper modifications.

Rule 3: Maintain internal and external consistency.

questions.question: A company wants to adopt the Agile Manifesto to increase productivity in the workplace and allow for a more flexible development of its products. What would a company adopting the Agile Manifesto MOST LIKELY be attempting to do?
questions.subject: Domain 8: Software Development Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Create software

A company creating software would use the Agile Manifesto. The Agile Manifesto is essentially a software development plan, not hardware development, that is associated with twelve principles to allow for creating and evolving software by adapting to customer and professional feedback.

The Agile Manifesto is not a government standard of any kind, although the word "manifesto" did originate in Italy. The Agile Manifesto is not related to any government's laws, regulations, or standards.

questions.question: Which of the following terms refers to a class of metrics that is used to measure activity success?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Security Assessment and Testing
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Key Performance Indicator

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are a class of metrics used to measure activity success. KPI measurements enable performance to be tracked, trended, monitored, and prioritized or targeted for improvement. Examples of KPIs include, "percent of system uptime" and "mean time to detect."

Key Risk Indicators (KRIs) are a class of metrics used to measure exposure to potential harm. Examples of KRIs include, "number of unplanned outages" and "number of perimeter breaches." A Business Impact Analysis (BIA) is performed during the initial stages of business continuity planning to identify and prioritize critical business processes. Recovery Point Objective (RPO) is the threshold (expressed as an interval of time) established by the organization to indicate the maximum amount of data loss it can tolerate without adverse impact. An organization that is unable to tolerate more than a day's worth of data loss would have an RPO of 24 hours.

questions.question: Which of the following types of plans describes how an organization's general security goals can be accomplished?
questions.subject: Domain 1: Security and Risk Management
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Tactical

Organizations can have three types of security plans:

  • Strategic plans are the longest type of security management plan. They describe overall security goals and can be viable for up to five years.
  • Tactical plans are the next longest and describe how particular goals can be accomplished. They're usually good for about a year.
  • Operational plans have an extremely short duration. They provide in-depth detail on how the organization will accomplish tasks to support their strategic or tactical plans.

Contingency plans are not one of the three types of security management plans.

questions.question: Which Bell-LaPadula rule is also known as the “no write down” rule?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Security Architecture and Engineering
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Star (*) property

The Bell-LaPadula Model has three main rules:

  1. Simple security property states that a subject may not access information that resides at a higher security level. Known as (no read up).
  2. Star (*) property states that a subject may not write information that resides at a lower security level. Known as (no write down).
  3. Strong star (*) property states that a subject may not read or write information that resides at any security level, except for the level the subject is a member of.

Simple integrity property is part of the Biba model and prevents a user from reading information that resides at a lower security level. Known as "no read down."

questions.question: Of the following, which protocol has native payload encryption?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Communication and Network Security
questions.explanation:
Correct answer: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec)

Internet Protocol Security (IPsec) is a suite of protocols that provides protection at the network layer of the Open System Interconnection (OSI) model. IPsec is frequently used to establish a Virtual Private Network (VPN) between two routers. IPsec protects the original IP packet by encrypting or hashing the IP packet and adding a new AH or ESP header with a new IP header. Layer 2 tunneling protocol (L2TP) uses IPsec to encrypt its tunnels. IPsec-specific protocols are:

  • Authentication Header (AH) provides integrity of the packet and adds an AH header.
  • Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) provides the confidentiality of the packet and adds an ESP header.
